title: Rex Tillerson won't condemn slashing cuts to agency budget
title_page: Rex Tillerson won't condemn slashing cuts to agency budget | Daily Mail Online
text:
Secretary of State Rex Tillerson indicated while traveling in Japan that he is willing to swallow the massive budget cuts that President Trump's first budget is imposing on his agency, saying he accepts the challenge 'willingly.'
Tillerson, the former Exxon CEO who has dined frequently with Trump during his early tenure, did not push back publicly after it was revealed State would absorb a 29 per cent cut – more than any agency except the Environmental Protection Agency, which is despised by some conservatives.
Asked about the cuts, which run from U.S. contributions to UN peacekeeping to direct aid programs to some of the world's poorest nations, Tillerson said the agency's budget had grown to large due to overseas conflicts.
'The level of spending that the State Department has been undertaking, particularly in the past year, is simply not sustainable,” Tillerson said.
Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said in Japan that he takes on the challenge of cutting his agency budget 'willingly'
'I take the challenge that the President has given us on willingly and with great expectation that with everyone in the State Department’s assistance, we’re going to deliver a much better result for the American people in the future.'
State would absorb a $10.9 billion cut in the next fiscal year under the Trump budget proposal.
Funding would drop from 38 per cent to 27.1 per cent – making the agency the biggest loser other than the EPA, an agency despised by some conservatives.
The 'Budget Blueprint to Make America Great Again' provides $2.2 billion for new embassy construction, and $3.1 billion in aide to Israel. It eliminates a Global Climate Change initiative, shifts foreign assistance from grants to loans in some cases, and shifts funds to areas with the 'greatest strategic importance.' It also reduces funds for cultural exchanges, and eliminates funds for small institutions like the East-West Center.

The State Department got hammered with a 29 per cent cut in the Trump administration's first budget proposal
Explaining the cuts, Tillerson said: 'As time goes by, there will be fewer military conflicts that the U.S. will be directly engaged in. And second .. as we become more effective in our aid programs, that we will also be attracting resources from other countries, allies, and other sources as well to contribute in our development aid and our disaster assistance.'
Tillerson, who got a $180 million package when he left Exxon, hailed the agency's staff. 'The men and women in the State Department are there for one reason. They’re not there for the glory. They’re not there for the money, obviously. They’re there because they’re extraordinarily dedicated to the mission and dedicated to ensuring America’s national security, economic security.'
The big cuts don't appear to be reflective of Tillerson's relationship with the president. He was dining at Trump's luxury hotel when Trump went out there to dinner there last month, and the two men visited.

State was the second-biggest agency loser in the 'America First' budget
On Sunday, Trump had dinner with Tillerson and his national security advisor at the White House.
He said the agency would be undertaking a 'very comprehensive examination of how programs are executed, a very comprehensive examination of how we are structured, and I’m confident that with the input of the men and women of the State Department, we are going to construct a way forward that allows us to be much more effective, much more efficient, and be able to do a lot with fewer dollars.'
He continued: 'So it’s challenging. We understand the challenge. I take the challenge that the President has given us on willingly and with great expectation that with everyone in the State Department’s assistance, we’re going to deliver a much better result for the American people in the future.'
